Award.AwardTitle: AF: Small: Collaborative Research: Principles of Robust Cooperative Computing in Dynamic Distributed Systems

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project investigates computability, algorithmics, and complexity in distributed settings with large numbers of machines cooperating on solving computation problems in the presence of dynamic changes in the computing medium. The computation problems are modeled as collections of tasks, such as the problems frequently occurring in the Internet supercomputing. This research has the potential to impact massive cooperative computing in dynamic settings through the use of rigorously developed algorithms with formally proved efficiency and fault-tolerance guarantees. In the longer term this research will also have impact on the development of broader classes of adaptive distributed systems.

This research develops advanced algorithms enabling efficient and fault-tolerant cooperative computing in dynamic distributed settings. The basic problem is formulated in terms of a collection of processors that need to perform a set of tasks, where the tasks must be executed using either at-least-once or at-most-once semantics. The research considers dynamic settings that are representative of situations in Internet supercomputing. The models of cooperation include: (a) oracle model, where a central authority provides information to the participants. (b) master-worker model, where a single master coordinates the workers in performing the tasks, a typical setting in Internet supercomputing. (c) peer-to-peer mode, where fully-distributed solutions will be investigated, enabling much more dynamic and fault-tolerant solutions. The investigation includes the associated resource discovery problem of identifying the nodes in the distributed system that are willing and able to cooperate; here the investigation focuses on more realistic settings than previously considered. This research also studies supporting services that can provide effective implementations of communication and shared-memory primitives in target dynamic platforms. The quality of algorithms is evaluated using corresponding lower bounds and impossibility results.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project studied computability issues, algorithmics, and complexity in distributed computing settings where large numbers of machines need to cooperate in solving specific computation problems in the presence of unpredictable changes in the computing medium. In this research we focus on the computation problems that are modeled as collections of similar, independent and idempotent tasks, such as the problems frequently occurring in the Internet supercomputing. We also consider efficient implementations of distributed supporting services, such as atomic memory abstraction in message-passing distributed settings. Lastly we consider optimizing deployment of abstract distributed systems on specific networked platforms.

 

The outcomes of the project closely correspond to the three main research areas: 1) Dsitributed cooperative problems, 2) Distributed resource discovery, and 3) Supporting services, where our focus was primarily on consistent replicated dsitributed memory services and built-in gossip services. The project develop a series of algorithms covering each area.

 

Intellectual merit:

 

Our research develops advanced algorithms enabling efficient and fault-tolerant cooperative computing in dynamic distributed settings. We also investigate the associated resource discovery problem dealing with the identification of the nodes in a distributed system that are willing and able to cooperate. Our initial approach is formulated in terms of the problem of p processors performing n tasks in a dynamic distributed setting. This problem and its derivatives have been a centerpiece in the study of trade-offs between efficiency and fault-tolerance in cooperative computing environments. We are considering various settings that are more dynamic than considered previously, and the failure models that are more representative of situations

in Internet supercomputing, including, for example, malicious (undependable) behavior of participating nodes. Moving beyond the setting with bounded numbers of tasks and processors, we will research the cooperation problem in the environments with dynamic collections of tasks and processors. This is representative of the trends observed in modern Internet supercomputing.

 

An indispensable first step enabling cooperative computing in dynamic settings is the resource discovery, and we will research algorithms and computability issues for this problem in more dynamic and more realistic settings than previously considered. This project also studies supporting services that can provide effective implementations of communication and shared-memory primitives in target dynamic platforms. The quality of our algorithms is evaluated using corresponding lower bounds and impossibility results.
